sn47.38:4.1: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn47.38:4.3: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.38:4.4: As they do so they completely understand the body.
sn47.38:4.5: When the body is completely understood they realize the deathless.
sn47.38:5.1: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.38:5.2: As they do so they completely understand feelings.
sn47.38:5.3: When feelings are completely understood they realize the deathless.
sn47.38:6.1: They meditate by observing an aspect of the mind, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.38:6.2: As they do so they completely understand the mind.
sn47.38:6.3: When the mind is completely understood they realize the deathless.
sn47.38:7.1: They meditate by observing an aspect of principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.38:7.2: As they do so they completely understand principles.
sn47.38:7.3: When principles are completely understood they realize the deathless.”
